docs.lead_paragraph: Enlisting Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor and a high-tech eye-tracking device developed for the military, researchers at Yale ran experiments that came closer than anything yet to offering a look at the world as seen through the eyes of people with autism. In one experiment, described in the current issue of The American Journal of Psychiatry, the researchers compared the eye movements of a highly intelligent autistic adult and a control subject of the same age, sex and I.Q. as they watched the relentless emotional conflicts of ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?''

headline.main: Experiment Offers Look Through Eyes of Autism

docs.abstract: Researchers at Yale Child Study Center, in paper published in American Journal of Psychiatry, find that autistic adults view things far differently than nonautistic but otherwise equal adults; autistics fitted with special eye-tracking devices and watching interactions between characters in movie Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? focused on actors' mouths while nonautistic adults focused on their eyes (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When a teenage girl develops anorexia, a team of experts usually takes charge of bringing her back to a normal weight, while her parents stand on the sidelines. But a promising and controversial new therapy gives parents the primary responsibility for an anorexic child's recovery.
docs.abstract: Article on promising but controversial new technique for treating anorexia, developed at Maudsley Hospital in London and being tested in US, in which parents are given primary responsibility for child's recovery; photos; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: When a teenage girl develops anorexia, a team of experts usually takes charge of bringing her back to a normal weight, while her parents stand on the sidelines.    But a promising and controversial new therapy gives parents the primary responsibility...

docs.lead_paragraph: What's the best way to live to 100? Have an older brother or sister who did. A study released yesterday in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences found what it called ''truly remarkable'' evidence of the strong role that genetic factors play in longevity. The study, led by Dr. Thomas Perls, the director of the New England Centenarian Study, looked at 2,092 siblings of 444 people who had lived to be 100 and compared them with information on the survival rates of Americans born in 1900.
docs.abstract: New England Centenarian Study director Dr Thomas Perls, reporting in Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences, finds remarkable evidence of strong role that genetics plays in longevity; finds large number of centenarians had older siblings who lived to be 100; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: What's the best way to live to 100? Have an older brother or sister who did.    A study released yesterday in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences found what it called ''truly remarkable'' evidence of the strong role that genetic...

docs.lead_paragraph: Like just about every fourth-year medical student, Nicole Fanarjian recently made the rounds of hospitals in search of a residency program that would train her for her specialty: obstetrics-gynecology. This spring, she visited 13 programs, and in nearly every interview, she asked this direct, but sometimes eyebrow-raising question: ''Do you provide residents with abortion training?'' ''I am planning to be an ob-gyn, and I intend to provide the full range of reproductive services, including abortion,'' said Ms. Fanarjian, 33, who will begin her residency at the University of South Florida in Tampa next month. ''I want to be exposed to the procedure, because I strongly believe that if you go into this specialty, you should feel comfortable providing abortions.''

headline.main: Newest Skill for Future Ob-Gyns: Abortion Training

docs.abstract: Article on increase in number of obstetrics-gynecology residency training programs that are adding abortion training; New York, where one in seven doctors in US does residency, soon will become first city to require abortion techniques as standard part of training at public hospitals; photos; graph (M)

The guidelines identify four categories of prospective patients for Lasik surgery, as the procedure is known. These are the categories:

docs.lead_paragraph: A study being released today has found that about half of a group of people with chronic asthma also suffered from low-level lung infections, and that antibiotic treatment improved their breathing. In recent years, many researchers have been investigating whether bacterial infections play a role in causing or worsening the lung inflammation that produces asthma.
docs.abstract: National Jewish Medical and Research Center, in study published in journal Chest, finds that about half of study group of 55 people with chronic asthma also suffered from low-level lung infections and that antibiotic treatment improves breathing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When someone at a party said, ''I don't eat carrots -- they have too much sugar'' and his companion replied, ''I don't eat corn or potatoes for the same reason,'' I realized there was an urgent need to put the so-called glycemic index into proper perspective before anyone else decided to avoid delicious, nutritious foods packed with health-protective substances. The glycemic index is a measure of how much carbohydrate-containing foods raise a person's fasting level of blood glucose and consequent need for insulin in two hours.

headline.main: Fear Not That Carrot, Potato or Ear of Corn

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column, noting that some diabetics believe that foods such as carrots, potatoes and corn must be avoided because they have high sugar content, describes realities of glycemic index; experts note index does not take into account caloric density of foods; more helpful gauge is glycemic load, which refers to blood glucose effect of standard serving rather than fixed amount of carbohydrate; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: When someone at a party said, ''I don't eat carrots -- they have too much sugar'' and his companion replied, ''I don't eat corn or potatoes for the same reason,'' I realized there was an urgent need to put the so-called glycemic index into proper...

docs.lead_paragraph: Recently my mother, 94, lay slowly dying. She was skeletal, feeble, disoriented, delusional and agitated, and she slept fitfully. She took water by medicine dropper and refused all food. Helpful, caring hospice and health care workers attended her in my brother's house around the clock. Three days later, although still occasionally confused, she sat at the kitchen table requesting pancakes for breakfast and making sharp-witted remarks. Two weeks later, her mental condition and energy level were essentially normal for the first time in years. A month later, her weight was normal.
docs.abstract: W David McCoy Cases essay describes how his bright, energetic, happy 94-year-old mother was brought to brink of death by doctors prescribing too many medications without considering side effects they were causing; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A study released last week has concluded that lung cancer rates in developing countries could be lowered sharply by a change relating to smoke that has nothing to do with tobacco: switching from fire pits to vented stoves. The study, published last week in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute, looked at cancer rates among 21,232 farmers born into households in Yunnan Province in China at a time when their families used smoky coal in fire pits for cooking and heating.
docs.abstract: Study led by Dr Qing Lan of Chinese Academy of Preventive Medicine, published in Journal of National Cancer Institute, concludes that lung cancer rates in developing countries could be lowered sharply by switching from smoky coal fire pits to vented stoves; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A study released last week has concluded that lung cancer rates in developing countries could be lowered sharply by a change relating to smoke that has nothing to do with tobacco: switching from fire pits to vented stoves.     The study, published...

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical journals are the prime source of information about scientific advances that can change how doctors treat patients in offices and in hospitals. And to ensure the quality of what journals publish, their editors, beginning 200 years ago, have increasingly called on scientific peers to review new findings from research in test tubes and on animals and humans. The system, known as peer review, is now considered a linchpin of science. Editors of the journals and many scientists consider the system's expense and time consumption worthwhile in the belief that it weeds out shoddy work and methodological errors and blunts possible biases by scientific investigators. Another main aim is to prevent authors from making claims that cannot be supported by the evidence they report.

headline.main: When Peer Review Produces Unsound Science

docs.abstract: Article on problems within scientific peer review system; Journal of American Medical Assn, after fourth meeting on research on peer review since 1989, reports considerable evidence that many statistical and methodological errors are common in published papers and that authors often fail to discuss limitations of their findings; journal editor Dr Drummond Rennie says that despite improvements, there is still massive amount of 'rubbish' published in medical journals; photo (M)
